Alice reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about 6 bags of maize per 1½ acres, but with her One Acre Fund input loan during Long Rains 2012, she harvested 37 bags per 1 1/2 acres! she plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and buy a cow. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Alice’s group will receive 10 1/2 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Elchin

texts.en: Elchin has been an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) from Fizuli city, but now he lives in the Fuzuli region with his family. He is married and has a child. Elchin is 24 years old. He has had his beauty salon for 2 years. Now he needs a 2,000 AZN loan to buy some new materials to repair his salon. He wants to improve his business. You can see in the photo that his salon is not in good condition.

loans.use: to buy some new materials to repair his salon.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is age twenty-eight and a farmer in Nkubu county where she lives with her husband and two children, only one of whom has started schooling. She has been practicing mixed farming for the past four years, producing vegetables, milk, bananas and other fruits which she sells at the local market.

She is requesting a 20,000 KES loan from Juhudi kilimo to purchase pigs from which she will sell the meat to get more income. That will help her improve her family’s livelihood and enable her to pay school fees for her children with some ease. She plans to have opened a slaughter house for pork in the next five years.

Insecurity is her major challenge in farming. Elizabeth says Juhudi kilimo is the best micro-finance institution for small scale farmers.

loans.use: To purchase pigs for pork.

loans.name: Anifa

texts.en:
Anifa is a married woman who has no children. She has a well-stocked food pantry in her home from which she sells to her neighbors and occasional customers. She offers beverages, sugar, rice, baked goods and other basic household necessities. By stocking her business with her own vegetables, she is able to generate a better profit.

The loan she is requesting will be used to buy products in bulk, such as meat, beverages, canned goods and other items. With the end of the year approaching, she wants to increase her stock since prices go up during this time. She wants to continue offering affordable prices to her customers.

loans.use: to buy products in bulk, such as meat, beverages, canned goods, and other items.

loans.name: Jitegemee Group

texts.en:
Christine is a member of the Jitegemee Group in Kakamega South District. She is pictured with 11 One Acre Fund farmers, 7 women and 4 men. Christine is standing on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation. Christine first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2009 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer.

Christine described her harvest as good last year as a One Acre Fund farmer and hopes for another good year in the 2013 Long Rains season. She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school and buy a cow. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Christine’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 5 1/2 acres of land.  

The field officer is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Rebecca's Group

texts.en: Rebecca is a 28-year-old mother of two and a tailor. Her husband is an electrician. Rebecca sees the KOMAZA microforestry program "as an investment for the future for my kids." With the income from her tree farm, Rebecca intends to send her children to school without financial strain, build a permanent home with electricity and improve her tailoring business. Also pictured with the group of nine is Dzame, who showed a great deal of interest in the KOMAZA tree-planting program but was unable to commit her family's time to an additional agricultural venture this season.

loans.use: to purchase tree farm supplies such as eucalyptus seedlings and fertilizer, as well as to pay for technical training and maintenance support.

loans.name: Thoa

texts.en:
Thoa was born in 1985. She has three daughters. Her oldest child is in the 1st grade. Two younger daughters are too young for school. Her husband and she are carpenters. Her income is about 5,000,000 dong [VND]. Her family’s total earnings are about 10,000,000 VND per month.
She joined SEDA's credit program in 2013. In this first loan cycle, she would like to borrow 5,152,000 VND to buy carpentry tools such as chisels and saws. She hopes to raise her children well and enlarge her wood workshop.

loans.use: to buy carpentry tools such as chisels and saws.

loans.name: Djahid

texts.en: Djahid is married and has 2 children. He has been an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) from occupied territories (Fizuli city). Now he lives in the Fuzuli region with his family. Djahid has been in this business for 3 years. Now he needs a 2,000 AZN (Azerbaijani New Manat) to buy livestock for his business. Djahid is 27 years old.

loans.use: to buy livestock.

loans.name: Dam

texts.en:
Dam was born in 1950. She has two children who are adults. Her husband is a worker. Dam is a worker and a farmer to earn a living. Her income is about 6,500,000 VND. Her family’s total earnings are about 10,000,000 VND per month. 

She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2010. In the last cycle she borrowed 7,840,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 9,632,000 VND to buy food for pigs.

loans.use: to buy food for pigs.

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en:
Jenifer is a 25-year-old farmer in Nkubu County where she lives with her husband and two children, only one has started school.  She has been in mixed farming for the past twelve years producing milk and vegetables which she sells to the people around her local area.

She is requesting a 20,000 KES loan from Juhudi kilimo to purchase water tanks that will help her in irrigating her crops. She will be in a position to get better produce that will give her more income to help her be able to take care of her family’s needs comfortably.  She plans to have opened a fully equipped veterinary shop in the next five years.

Drought, pests and diseases are her major challenges in farming.
Jenifer is happy with the affordable interest rates offered by Juhudi Kilimo.

loans.use: to purchase water tanks for irrigation.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is married and lives with her three children. She learnt to be a dressmaker by working as a seamstress in a factory producing wind proof jackets. She was able to save money over the years, and as a result, buy a sewing machine and start up her business. At the present time, she is one of the best known people for sewing articles of clothing, jackets, curtains, sheets, etc.
The loan that Amina has applied for is intended for the purchase of fabrics and other articles, so as to be able to satisfy her customer’s wishes. In this way, she intends to offer them better services.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and other articles to aid in her tailoring business.

loans.name: Tai

texts.en:
Tai was born in 1963. He has two children who are workers. His wife sells rice to earn a living. Her income is about 4,000,000 dong [VND]. Tai raises pigs to earn a living. He gets about 3,500,000 VND per month. His family’s total earnings are about 10,000,000 VND per month.
He has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2008. In the last cycle he borrowed 9,184,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, he would like to borrow 10,080,000 VND to buy food for pigs. He wants to enlarge his farm of pigs.

loans.use: to buy food for his pigs.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet from Kisauni, is married and has two children. She is a hairdresser and she also sells sewing supplies and shoes. She has loyal customers, because she always gives good service.

She is a hardworking person, responsible and very honest. She started to work in a hair salon as a secretary and her dream was to become a professional and to have her own salon. With time, sacrifice and hard work she was able to reach her goal.
She is now requesting a loan to expand her beauty salon and in this way to be able to continue growing and to offer better services to her customers.

loans.use: to expand her beauty salon.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is married and has four children, all of whom attend school. She is a tailor who, over time and after getting experience, opened her own workshop. She began with a single sewing machine and now has two. Her husband is a technician and between them they have provided everything for their children.

In the future, her goal is to expand her workshop and to buy more machines and provide jobs for others. She is applying for this loan so that she can buy fabric and thread to keep working and meeting her customers’ needs.

loans.use: to buy fabric and thread for her sewing.

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris is from Kisauni, and operates a small hair salon. She wants to remodel her salon in order to offer her clients a more comfortable environment, and generate more income to help support her family. She is requesting this loan in order to help grow her business.

She is a very hardworking person with a persistent spirit and attitude. She has much experience in her field, and knows what she is doing. Her goal is to one day have a large beauty salon, and to be widely known for her talent. She is grateful for this opportunity, and believes that the support will be a great help to her.

loans.use: to remodel her beauty salon.

loans.name: Trang

texts.en:
Trang was born in 1990. She has two daughters who are a four and two years old. Her husband is a carpenter and earns about 4,000,000 VND per month. Trang also is a carpenter. Her income is about 3,000,000 VND. She has done this job for 4 years. Her family’s total earnings are about 7,000,000 VND per month.

She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2011. In the last cycle she borrowed 7,392,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,288,000 VND to buy wood for her carpentry workshop. She aspires to raise her children well.

loans.use: to buy wood for her carpentry workshop.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose sells a variety of products in her store. Managing her business involves offering merchandise and accepting payments over both the short and long term. This type of work allows her to provide jobs to other people since she has many customers.

Rose is an entrepreneur who strives every day to improve the stability of her family. Her objective going forward is to establish a wholesale shop for the delivery of her merchandise. She is requesting this loan so that she can buy a variety of products to sell. This will enable her to continue working and improve the range she can offer to her customers.

loans.use: to buy a variety of merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is a Ghanaian artisan who specializes in transforming natural fibers into elegant handbags. He would like to purchase considerable amounts of raffia rope, jute, threads and lining fabric to increase production.

Paul has been selling through NOVICA since 2009. This is his story:

"My late uncle taught me to weave with corn husks, but after three months, he abandoned the work because it wasn't lucrative. I decided that I would pursue this art and come up with new, attractive designs. Initially, I was creating small bags and customers encouraged me to continue. I work with all kinds of materials – corn husks, plantain leaves, kente cloth, fabric, leather, plywood, foam, raffia, twine and cotton cord. I've had the opportunity to teach over a hundred young people how to weave with corn husks. My ambition is to eventually establish a big workshop to train youths who are interested in this craft and to be able to produce new designs on a larger scale."

"I thank you all for supporting my work with this microcredit. It is much appreciated!"

Use the link below to view Paul's natural fiber handbags on the NOVICA site:

http://www.novica.com/kiva/7206

loans.use: to purchase considerable amounts of raffia rope, jute, threads and lining fabric to increase production.

loans.name: The Star Group

texts.en:
Hadiatu is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Hadiatu was born in Yoni, in northern Sierra Leone 28 years ago. She is married to a carpenter and the couple has 2 children who are attending primary school. Hadiatu sells ready-to-wear-clothes and has been doing this business for many years now.

With the help of this loan, Hadiatu and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. Hadiatu will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to buy ready-to-wear-clothes in a larger quantity to add to her current stock for sale.

loans.use: to buy ready-to-wear-clothes in a larger quantity to add to her current stock for sale.

loans.name: Action Group 2

texts.en:
Marie is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Marie was born in Mile-Ninety-One, in northern Sierra Leone, 41 years ago. She is married to a trader and the couple has 4 children who are attending primary and secondary schools. Marie sells sugar, rice, and other items; she has been doing this business for many years now.

With the help of this loan, Marie and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Marie will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to buy a large quantity of sugar and rice to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy a large quantity of sugar and rice to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Mario's Group

texts.en:
Mario is 61 years old and lives in Butuay, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. He is widowed with 3 children. 

Mario has an eatery business and earns approximately 3,500 PHP each month doing this type of work. He has requested a loan to purchase meat, ingredients and other goods for his mini-eatery.

Mario has been a member of PMPC almost 2 years. In the future, Mario hopes to engage in other types of business. Mario is the leader of a 2-person group. Although they borrow as a group, each member of the group has his own business.

loans.use: to purchase meat, ingredients and other goods for his eatery.

loans.name: Luong's Group

texts.en:
Luong was born in 1967. She has two children who are a worker and a supermarket cashier. Her husband is dead. Luong collects iron scrap to earn a living. She gains from her job 3,500,000 VND a month. Her family’s total earnings are about 10,000,000 VND per month.
She joined SEDA's credit program in 2013. In this first loan cycle, she would like to borrow 5,152,000 VND to buy more iron scraps to recycle. She wants to save more money for her family.

Other members which are part of Luong's group include the following:
Hong is 55 years old. She has a child. She wants to borrow 5,152,000 VND to raise chikens.
Tam is 22 years old. She has a child. She wants to borrow 5,152,000 VND to sell food in the market.
Thanh is 26 years old. He has two children. He wants to borrow 5,152,000 VND to buy food for his pigs.

loans.use: to buy more iron scraps to recycle.

loans.name: Tamemkoh Group

texts.en:
Adama is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Adama was born in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone 27 years ago. She is married to a tailor and the couple has 2 children who are attending primary school. Adama sells ready-to-wear-clothes and has been doing this business for many years now.
With the help of this loan, Adama and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. Adama will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to buy ready-to-wear-clothes in a larger quantity to have for sale.

loans.use: to buy ready-to-wear-clothes in a larger quantityto have for sale.

loans.name: Kibibi

texts.en:
Kibibi is a widow, has five children, and lives in Kisauni. She has a well-stocked grocery store. She says she started with a small store and later changed areas and now has her grocery store. It has gone very well for her, with regular customers because of her longevity in the location.

She's requesting the loan to buy beverages, canned goods, vegetables, and other supplies for her business because these are the most popular.
She's grateful for the help she gets because it will be very useful to her.

loans.use: to buy beverages, canned goods, vegetables, and other supplies for her store.

loans.name: Charlie

texts.en:
When Charlie accepted a driving position at a trucking company four years ago, he never dreamed he would someday venture off on his own as an independent contractor.

“Never in a million years did I think I’d be doing this,” Charlie says.

While it wasn’t his original goal, Charlie has excelled in his work and found his niche. Being self-employed is just the appropriate next step. Charlie will use his Kiva loan to help him purchase his own truck, the primary expense to being an independent contractor. 

Charlie looks forward to the opportunity. He says, for his personality, it’s much more motivating to be paid in the stops and miles versus in hours worked. 

“I love making my own schedule, going to work when I feel like it, and being more independent overall,” he says. 

Charlie was born and raised in New Orleans and although some jobs take him to other locations around Southeast Louisiana, he says he enjoys that most of his days are spent driving around the city, hauling shipping containers on his truck. 

“Being on the road every day, you get to see what’s going on,” he says.  

Charlie is ready to revel in his new freedom as his own boss, but at the same time, he already has his eye on the future. His ultimate goal is to purchase at least two or three additional trucks and hire drivers under him. He likes the idea of creating jobs in the community and helping others get their start in a career he finds rewarding.

To get there, Charlie will be diligently saving his profits. While it can be difficult to put away savings, Charlie says it’s easy when you know exactly what you are going to do with the funds. Despite not envisioning this path four years ago, today Charlie says he knows exactly where he’s going and looks forward to growing his business for years to come.

loans.use: To purchase his own truck for transporting goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to update his equipment.

loans.name: Ma. Theresa

texts.en:
Ma. Theresa is 52 years old and lives in Rizal, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is married with three children. 

Ma. Theresa is engaged in the hog fattening business and earns approximately PHP 3,000 each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan to be used in purchasing additional sacks of feed for her hog fattening activity. 

Ma. Theresa joined PMPC just last Dec. 2012. In the future,  Ma. Theresa hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional sacks of feed

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is 59 years old and married with nine children. With two children currently in school, Anita works very hard to provide for them.

Anita runs a business buying and selling charcoal in the Philippines and requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell. She has been in this business for five years.

In the future Anita would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Edgardo

texts.en:
Edgardo works hard to support his family. He is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Edgardo requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, eggs, soap, snack foods, etc. He has been in this business for six years now.

In the future, Edgardo would like to build and expand his business to secure the financial stability of his family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, eggs, soap, snack foods, etc

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora is married with three children. She is 50 years old and lives in ZNAC, Tampilisan, Zamboanga del Norte.

Aurora owns a store to earn a living and had this business for 10 years. Each month, she earns 3000 PHP doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase more stock  such as toothpaste, soap and other items to sell.

Aurora has been a member of PMPC for two years. In the future, Aurora hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock  such as toothpaste, soap and other items to sell

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. Elvira has been in this business for 4 years. Elvira earns more income from raising pigs.

She is borrowing 50000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of items like salted egg, soft drinks, sugar, and noodles to sell in her general store business.

Elvira has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of salted egg, soft drinks, sugar, and noodles to sell.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 37 years old and married, with five children who are currently going to school. Erlinda works very hard to provide for them.

Erlinda runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a loan of 15000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of soft drinks, soap, oil, and other groceries needed in her business. Erlinda has been in this business for 5 years.

In the future, Erlinda would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of soft drinks, soap, oil, and other groceries needed in her business.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Evelyn works hard to support her family. She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling livestock.

Evelyn is borrowing 10000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional ingredients and other cooking materials for her food vending business.

Evelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past two loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to provide a secure the future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients and other cooking materials for her business.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Helen works hard to support her family. She has a motorycle transport business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from farming sugarcane. 

Helen is borrowing 29500 PHP through NWTF to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

Helen has been sustaining her business activities through her past 22 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle business.

loans.name: Gaudiosa

texts.en:
Gaudiosa is 52 years old and lives in Gil Sanhez, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is married with six children.

To earn a living, Gaudiosa has a business selling a variety of foods for snacks. She earns about 5000 PHP each month doing this type of work. Gaudiosa has requested a loan to purchase more raw ingredients for her snack vending business.

Gaudiosa has been a member of PMPC for three years. In the future, Gaudiosa would like to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more raw ingredients for her snack vending business

location.town: Liloy-Gil Sanchez, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Sunrise Center Group

texts.en:
Emma is maried with six children. She is 56  years old and lives in the Philippines.

Emma is a farmer and grows pigs to earn a living. She has doing this for 20 years. She requested a loan to purchase more pigs to grow. 

Emma has been  a member of PMPC for six years. In the future, she hopes to buy a car for transporting her pigs.

loans.use: to purchase feed for hog raising

location.town: Pagadian - Lower Bagong Silang  Pagadian City

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda works hard to support her family. Imelda is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Imelda requested a 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to purchase items to sell like soap, canned goods, eggs, spices, etc.

Imelda has been in this business for six years now.

In the future, Imelda would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase items to sell like soap, canned goods, eggs, spices, etc.

loans.name: Pilar Jane

texts.en:
Pilar Jane is 25 years old and lives in Namnama, Titay, Zamboanga Sibugay. She is married with two children.

To earn a living, Pilar Jane has a business selling barbecue. She earns about 3000 PHP each month doing this type of work. Pilar Jane has a requested  loan to purchase more meat to cook as barbecue to retail.

Pilar Jane has been a member of PMPC for two years. In the future, Pilar Jane would like to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more meat to cook as barbecue

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is 38 years old and lives in Poblacion, Titay, Zamboanga Sibugay. She is married with two children.

Elsie has a sari-sari (variety) store. She is also an Avon dealer and sells RTW (ready-to-wear) products. She earns approximately 25,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan to purchase more products such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap, vinegar and salt to sell.

Elsie has been a member of PMPC since 2012. In the future, Elsie hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more products such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap, vinegar and salt to sell.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is married with six children. She is 55 years old and lives in Poblacion, Titay, Zamboanga Sibugay. Elizabeth owns a general store to earn a living and has had this business for 20 years. Each month, she earns 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase more stock for her general store such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap, salt, etc.

Elizabeth is a new member of PMPC. In the future, Elizabeth hopes to expand her store.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her general store such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap, salt, etc.

loans.name: Ma. Luz

texts.en:
Ma. Luz is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 10,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of items like biscuits, soft drinks, soap, and other groceries to sell in her general store.

Ma. Luz has been in this business for 18 years. She earns additional income by buying and selling livestock and selling Avon.

Ma. Luz has sustained her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure her family's future.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of items like biscuits, soft drinks, and soap to sell.

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn is 45 years old and married with four children. She works hard to provide for her family. Marlyn runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 22,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy stock to sell like eggs, bottled water, sardines, noodles, etc.

Marlyn has borrowed and repaid 10 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 15 years and also earns income from a photocopier. Marlyn hopes to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy stock to sell like eggs, bottled water, sardines, noodles, etc.

loans.name: Merceditha

texts.en: Merceditha is married and has four children, who are in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Merceditha is 45 years old and has a general store in the Philippines. She has applied for a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF to buy stocks to sell, including snack foods, soap, eggs, sugar and coffee. Merceditha has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, Merceditha would like to save enough money so she could afford for her children to finish college.

loans.use: to buy stocks to sell in her store, including snack foods, soap, eggs, sugar and coffee.

loans.name: Cherry

texts.en: Cherry is married and works hard to support her family. She has a fish-vending business in the Philippines. Cherry is borrowing PHP 13,000 through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. to buy more fish to sell to customers. Cherry has sustained her business activities through her past 12 loans from NWTF and, more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell to customers.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes is 63 years old and married with six children.

She earns a living by pig fattening in the Philippines. Lourdes is borrowing 29,500 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Lourdes has been pig fattening for two years and also earns additional income from a general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Rona

texts.en: Rona is 31 years old and married. Rona is in the agricultural business, fattening pigs in the Philippines. Rona requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. Rona has been in the pig-fattening business for a year now, and she has borrowed 9 times in the past from NWTF to sustain the business. In the future, Rona would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pig-fattening business.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en: Thelma is 60 years old and married. Thelma is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. Thelma requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pig. Thelma has been raising pigs for nine years, and she has borrowed from NWTF 17 times to sustain the business. In the future, Thelma would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her business raising pigs.

loans.name: Charina

texts.en: Charina is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a clothing sales business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 22,000 through NWTF to purchase more items like blouses, pants, slippers and school supplies. Charina successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business. NWTF is relisting Charina's business profile in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell, such as blouses, pants, slippers and school supplies.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Estrella works hard to support her family.

She buys and sells nipa (woven palm mats used for house repair and construction) as a business in the Philippines, and she also earns additional income from food vending and a general store. Estrella is borrowing 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to purchase additional stock of nipa to sell for her business.

Estrella has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of nipa (woven palm mats) to sell.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Delia works hard to support her family.

She has a fruits and vegetables retail business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from fish vending. Delia is borrowing 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to purchase fruits and vegetables to sell in her food stall.

Delia has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fruits and vegatables to sell in her food stall.

loans.name: Rubelyn

texts.en:
Rubelyn works hard to support her family. Rubelyn is married and has a buying and selling of rice business in the Philippines.

Rubelyn requested a 13,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy additional rice to sell.

Rubelyn has been in this business for four years now.

In the future, Rubelyn would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional rice to sell.

loans.name: Nury Lizeth

texts.es:
La señora  Nury tiene 34 años, es casada, tiene 2 hijos, reside junto a su familia en una comunidad del   Municipio de Tela, departamento de Atlántida.
Inicio su negocio hace 4 años, ella se dedica a la venta de ropa y cosméticos de manera ambulante y en su vivienda.
Debido al alto costo de la vida, Nury decidió obtener otros ingresos a través de la venta de ropa y así apoyar económicamente a su hogar.
Con el fin de aumentar sus ventas y aprovechar la época de verano decidió solicitar un préstamo por la cantidad de 17,000 Lempiras, los que piensa invertir en la compra de pantalones, camisas, camisetas, short, calzonetas y ropa interior, maquillaje, cosméticos y perfumes.
Nury se siente motivada con su negocio ya que sus ingresos le sirven para apoyar a sus hijos en la educación escolar.
texts.en:
Nury, age 34, is married and has two children.  She lives with her family in a community in the Tela municipality in the Atlántida department.

She started her business four years ago.  She sells clothes and cosmetics in an itinerant manner and at her house.

Due to the high cost of living, Nury decided to get other income by selling clothes.  This way she helps her household financially.

In order to increase sales and take advantage of the summer season, she decided to request a loan for 17,000 lempiras.  She plans to use the loan to buy pants, shirts, t-shirts, shorts, bathing suits, underwear, make-up, cosmetics, and perfume.

Nury is motivated by her business because this income serves to support her children’s education.

loans.use: to buy pants, shirts, t-shirts, shorts, bathing suits, underwear, make-up, cosmetics, and perfume.

loans.name: Dioqueta

texts.en:
Dioqueta is 59 years old, married and has nine children, one of whom is in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Dioqueta has a fish vending business in the Philippines. Dioqueta requested a 13,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan amount through NWTF to buy more fish to sell.

Dioqueta has been in this business for five years. In the future, Dioqueta would like to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma, who is married, works hard to support her family. For five years now she has been operating a business making and selling jewelry in the Philippines.

Gemma has requested a PHP 11000 loan through NWTF to buy materials needed for her enterprise. In the future, she would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy materials needed for her jewelry.

loans.name: Ma Gloridalma

texts.es:
La señora  Gloridalma tiene 38 años, es casada, tiene 4 hijos, reside junto a su familia en una comunidad rural del   Municipio de Arizona, departamento de Atlántida.
Hace 9 años inicio su negocio de venta de productos de la canasta básica familiar. Ella decidió establecer éste negocio con el ánimo de conseguir ingresos económicos para apoyar a su familia.
Actualmente ha solicitado un préstamo por la cantidad de 10,000 Lempiras, los que piensa invertir en la compra de más inventario como ser: pan, carnes, granos básicos, medicamentos de uso común, churros, golosinas, huevos, refrescos y condimentos.
Gloridalma se muestra satisfecha con el desarrollo de su negocio ya que las utilidades que obtiene le permiten crecer y mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Gloridalma, age 38, is married and has four children.  She lives with her family in a rural community in the Arizona municipality in the Atlántida department.

She started her business of selling basic needs products nine years ago.  She decided to establish this business with the thought of getting income to help her family.

She is currently requesting a loan for 10,000 lempiras to buy more inventory like bread, meats, basic grains, common use medications, churros, candy, eggs, soft drinks, and condiments.

Gloridalma is happy with the development of her business because the profits that she gets allow her to grow and improve her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: to buy more inventory like bread, meats, basic grains, common use medications, churros, candy, eggs, soft drinks, and condiments.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Delia works hard to support her family. She has a business selling purified drinking water in the Philippines and also earns additional income from a general store. Delia is borrowing 14,000 Philippine pesos through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.

Delia has been sustaining her business activities through her past eight loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of purified water to sell.

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
Julita is 43 years old and married with three children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Julita has a recycled materials business in the Philippines. Julita requested a 13,500 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to purchase recycled materials like plastic, cans and used papers.

Julita has been in her business for four years. In the future, Julita would like to save enough money to build a variety store.

loans.use: to purchase recycled materials like plastic, cans and used papers.

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en: Jacinta is 61 years old, married and has five children. She is in an agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines. Jacinta requested a 23,000 Philippine peso loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation to buy feed and vitamins for her livestock. Jacinta has been raising pigs for ten years now and has borrowed 26 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. In the future, Jacinta would like to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her livestock.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en: Arlene works hard to support her family. Arlene is married and has a tailoring business in the Philippines. She requested a 19,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy materials for her tailoring business like linen, tailoring chalk, etc. Arlene has been in her business for five years now. In the future, Arlene would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy materials for her tailoring business like linen, tailoring chalk, etc.

loans.name: Ma. Socorro

texts.en:
Ma. Socorro, 49, is married and has six children, two of whom are in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Ma. Socorro has a buying and selling kasoy seeds (cashew nuts) business in the Philippines. 

Ma. Socorro requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of kasoy seeds to sell. 

Ma. Socorro has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, Ma. Socorro would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of kasoy seeds to sell.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is married and works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling used clothing.  

Jocelyn is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell at her store.

Jocelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past 18 loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so that she can continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell at her store.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is 27 years old and married. She has three children.

She earns a living by farming vegetables in the Philippines. Emily has been farming vegetables for three years and also earns additional income from shell craft making.

Emily is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and farm equipment.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and farm equipment.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is a 42-year-old widow with three children who are currently in school. Evelyn works very hard to provide for them.

Evelyn buys and sells charcoal and rice in the Philippines. Evelyn has been in this business for four years.

She requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal and rice to sell.

In the future, Evelyn would like to save enough money so she could afford to finish the education of her children in college.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of charcoal and rice to sell.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna is 37 years old and married. She has three children.

Lorna works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to buy items like sardines, groceries, etc,. to sell in her sari-sari store.

Lorna has been in this business for six years and has previously received funds through Kiva.

Lorna aspires to save enough money to continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items like sardines, groceries, etc., to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling charcoal in the Philippines. Nelia has been in this business for 4 years. Nelia earns more income from farming vegetables, raising pigs and buying and selling coconut.

She is borrowing 15,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell. Nelia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita is 41 years old and married with two children. Rosita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a used clothing business in the Philippines and requested a 28,000 PHP loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. to buy items like bags, pants, t-shirts and other ready-to-wear clothing. Rosita has borrowed and repaid 14 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the used clothing business for 12 years and also earns an income from a general store.

Rosita aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items like bags, pants, t-shirts and other ready-to-wear clothing.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith works hard to support her family. Judith is married and has a motorcycle parts business in the Philippines. She requested a 10,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell. Judith has been in her business for one year now. In the future, Judith would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional motorcycle parts to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 42 years old and married with two children who are in school. Elizabeth works very hard to provide for them.

Elizabeth runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional stock to sell like soap, canned goods, spices, soft drinks, etc.. Elizabeth has been in this business for 7 years.

In the future, Elizabeth would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell like soap, canned goods, spices, soft drinks, etc.

loans.name: Gleceria

texts.en:
Gleceria is 49 years old, married with one child who is in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Gleceria has a restaurant business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 7 years. Gleceria requested a 20,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional ingredients for her restaurant business.

 In the future, Gleceria would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients for her restaurant business

loans.name: Lyndelou

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Lyndelou works hard to support her family. She has a business selling ready-to-wear [clothing] in the Philippines and also earns additional income from direct selling Avon products. Lyndelou is borrowing 25,000 Philippine pesos through NWTF to purchase additional ready-to-wear stock to sell for her business.

Lyndelou has been sustaining her business activities with her past eight loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of ready-to-wear to sell

loans.name: Febe

texts.en:
Febe is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling rice and charcoal in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of rice and charcoal to sell for her buy and sell rice and charcoal business.

Febe has been in this business for 16 years. She earns more income from farming sugarcane and vegetables.

Febe has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice and charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Ansole

texts.en:
Ansole works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for six years now, and also earns additional income from a general store.

Ansole successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her fish vending and general store business. She requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell.

In the future, Ansole would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell.

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta is 64 years old and a widow with four children. She earns a living by fattening pigs in the Philippines. Loreta is borrowing 14,000 Philippine pesos through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. Loreta has been pig fattening for four years and also earns additional income from food vending. 

Loreta has successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her pig fattening and food vending businesses. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling root crops in the Philippines. She has been in this business for eight years. She earns more income from farming corn and sugarcane and also pig fattening.

Lorena is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of root crops to sell for her buy and sell root crops business.

Lorena has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to school in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of root crops to sell.

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en: Felisa is 48 years old, married and has four children. She is in an agricultural business raising a cow in the Philippines. Felisa requested a 29,500 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to purchase an additional cow and other livestock to raise. Felisa has been raising cows for 29 years now and has borrowed 21 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. In the future, Felisa would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to purchase an additional cow and other livestock to raise

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is 36 years old, married and has one child who is currently in school. 

Mary Ann is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Mary Ann has been pig fattening for five years now, and has borrowed seven times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Mary Ann would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Maphie

texts.en:
Maphie is married with four children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She is 38 years old and has four children who are in school.

Maphie has a food vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for seven years. She requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional ingredients for her business.

In the future, Maphie would like to save enough money so she can afford to finish the education of her children in college.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients for her business.

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Jenelyn is 25 years old and married with 2 children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Jenelyn is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase materials for the maintenance of her pig pens.

Jenelyn has been raising pigs for 6 years and also earns additional income from buying and selling vegetables.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase materials for the maintenance of her pig pens

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en: Edwin is a 34-year-old married man. He has 1 child. He describes himself to be a visionary and honest man. He operates a retail store where he sells household items such as soda, flour, maize flour, etc. He has been involved in this business for 8 years. His business is located at an urban area and his primary customers are daily consumers and local residents within the area. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insecurity within the area. He will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy household products to sell. His business goal is to open another similar retail store within 5 years. He hopes that in the future, he will improve his business. This is his second loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy household products to sell

loans.name: Brigda

texts.en: Bridga is a 36-year-old married woman. She has 2 children with ages ranging from 3 years to 7 years. She describes herself to be a hardworking and caring woman. She operates a tailoring retail store where she sells dresses, skirts, suits, etc. She has been involved in this business for 7 years. Her business is located at an urban area, and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of finances for improving the business. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy fabric for making dresses and suits to sell. Her business goal is to improve her business within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will have a wholesale tailoring business. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy fabric to make dresses and suits to sell

loans.name: Kibibi

texts.en: Kibibi is married and has three children. She describes herself as a focused woman. She operates a retail business where she sells firewood. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in a viable business area and her primary customers are local residents. She says her biggest business challenge is a shortage of firewood to sell. She will use the loan of 80,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) to buy more firewood to sell. Her business goal is to run a bigger business selling firewood within five years. This is her third loan with SMEP DTM after managing to pay loans of 20,000 and 50,000 KES successfully.

loans.use: to buy firewood to sell.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene is married and works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines. Arlene is borrowing 14,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy fishing net and other fishing equipment.

Arlene has been sustaining her business activities through her past six loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy fishing net and other fishing equipment.

loans.name: Jerusha

texts.en: Jerusha is a 36-year-old married woman. She has 4 children. She describes herself to be a hardworking and determined woman. She operates a tailoring retail store where she sells dresses, skirts, suits, etc. She has been involved in this business for 6 years. Her business is located at a residential area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy fabric for making suits and dresses to sell. Her business goal is to expand her business and run another tailoring retail store within 5 years. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy fabric

loans.name: Imani Group

texts.en:
Imani Group is located in Kakamega South District. It is a group of nine women and three men led by Beatrice pictured on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for half an acre of maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. Beatrice first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains season and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Beatrice joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and access the best input prices. 

Beatrice reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about four bags of maize per 0.75 acre, but with her One Acre Fund input loan during Long Rains 2012, she harvested nine bags per 0.75 acre! She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school and invest in a cow. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive half an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Beatrice’s group will receive 5.5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.en:
Gregoria is 62 years old and married with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Gregoria has a sari-sari store business in the Philippines. Gregoria requested a PHP 10000 loan amount through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her sari-sari store.

Gregoria has been in this business for two years. In the future, Gregoria would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Melecia

texts.en:
Melicia is married and works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through Negros Women Tomorrow Foundation, Inc., to purchase more grocery products to sell at her store.

Melicia has been in this business for three years and has previously received funds through Kiva.

Melicia aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery products to sell at her store.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is a married woman. She has two children between the ages of 5 and 8. She describes herself to be a jovial and honest woman. She operates a retail business where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for seven years. Her business is located at a viable business area. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of enough funds for improving the business. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy clothes to sell. Her business goal is to run a wholesale business selling clothes within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will run a stable business and improve the living standard of her family. Sarah also gets some income to boost her business from her husband, who is employed as a taxi driver. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a married woman. She has two children who are 1 year and 3 years old. She describes herself to be a jovial, ambitious and smart woman. She operates a beauty salon where she provides hair services. She has been involved in this business for 14 years. Her business is located near a school, and her primary customers are students and the general public from the local environs. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. 

She will use the 30,000 KES (Kenyan shillings) loan to buy another dryer which will be used in her beauty salon to meet the customers' demand for hair service. Her business goal is to run a new business of a gym within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will build a permanent house. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM after taking a loan of 20,000 KES, which she repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy a dryer.

loans.name: Laarni

texts.en:
Laarni is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a tailoring business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 17000 through NWTF to buy materials needed for her tailoring business.

Laarni successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further improve her business.

NWTF is relisting Laarni's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy materials needed for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Perseveranda

texts.en:
Perseveranda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has operated a tricycle transportation business in the Philippines for four years. She also earns income from a general store.

Perseveranda, who has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF, is borrowing PHP 15000 to buy spare parts for her tricycle. She dreams of repairing and renovating her family home in the future.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for her tricycle.

loans.name: David

texts.en: David is a 35-year-old married man. He has three children with ages ranging from 5 years to 14 years. He describes himself to be a faithful man. He operates a van in which he provides transportation services. He has been involved in this business for 15 years. His business is located at a viable business area and his primary customers are local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. He will use the KES 30,000 loan to add to his savings and buy a van. His business goal is to own three vehicles within five years. He hopes that in the future he will educate his children with profits generated from the business. This is his third loan with SMEP DTM. He managed to pay a loan of KES 20,000 successfully.

loans.use: to add to his savings and buy a secondhand van

loans.name: Silveriana

texts.en:
Silveriana is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a native hat making business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 14000 through NWTF to buy materials like buri (raffia), paint, etc. for her native hat-making business.

Silveriana successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to improve her business.

NWTF is relisting Silveriana's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy materials like buri (raffia), paint etc. for her native hat-making business.

loans.name: Verginia

texts.en:
Verginia is a married and hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 30000 through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell for her general store business.

Verginia successfully paying back her previous loan and now is requesting a new loan for build and expand her business.

NWTF is relisting Verginia's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Tharo Group

texts.en: Thethem belongs to Tharo Group. She is pictured here with her hand raised. She lives with her husband and two children in a small village in Manipur, Northeast India. Jimmy, her husband, works for a meager income in the construction of houses. In order to supplement the family income, Thethem has been running a paan dukan (corner shop) near her house. However, due to lack of capital, she was not in a position to fill her shelves, so she lost some of her customer base. In order to attract more customers, she wants to use a loan to increase her shop’s stock of a variety of items including snacks, tobacco and other household essentials like matches, candles and soap. Since her eldest child will start school this year, Thethem hopes that making good use of this loan in her business will help her support this education. Moreover, she and her husband are hopeful about her venture. Likewise, the rest of the group members need a loan for their respective activities which are selling and supplying vegetables and running tea hotels.

loans.use: to buy materials and items for a paan shop

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia is a 40-year-old married woman with three children. She describes herself as an honest woman. Sofia operates a restaurant where she sells food, tea, and snacks; she has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a viable business area and her primary customers are local residents, but her biggest business challenge is insufficient funds for improving the business. Sofia will use her loan 30,000 of Kenyan Shillings (KES) to buy ingredients for preparing the food at her restaurant. 

Sofia also has rental houses which provide accommodation and increase her business income. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for preparing meals to sell.
